Um, everyone, do I spend too much time talking about the history and culture of my world? It's... the only real value I got out of my upbringing, so... I might overdo it sometimes.
The Red Moon in my world is associated with fire and power. Because so many Red moonstones fall on the lands of Nasr, they've become a desert where plant life cannot grow.

The Silver Moon in my world is associated with both life and death, the element of void. I'm... the only Silvite left, I guess. The Elders sacrificed themselves to save us, then Ramirez... actually, maybe I won't keep talking about this.
The Green Moon in my world is associated with growth and healing. Because it shines strongly over Ixa'taka, that country is covered in lush jungles and forests teeming with life.
The Blue Moon in my world is associated with wind and water. The people of Yafutoma use its power to build ships that can fly far higher or lower in the sky than those of other nations.

The Purple Moon in my world is associated with ice and the mind. It shines over the Lands of Ice, which are uninhabited by humans today. The fate of the civilization that lived there originally is unknown.
The Yellow Moon in my world is associated with electricity. It creates great thunderclouds over the nation of Valua, which provide abundant power, but also perpetually cover the land in darkness.

In addition to the six ordinary Moons in my world, it's possible a Black Moon exists. There's a Moon Stone in the Dark Rift that might have come from a hypothetical Black Moon... but if it's real, nothing is known about it.

Rather than use their powerful magic and technology to aid the poor and needy, the ancient civilizations of my world created terrible living weapons called the Gigas, and set them against each other in battle. It was the Gigas that brought an end to the Old World... so many people died as a result.

Our world has six Moons, each of a different color... Green, Red, Blue, Purple, Yellow, and Silver. Each has a different power channeled through the Moon Stones that fall from the sky. Moon Stones are used in many types of advanced technology, such as airships, and can also be used to perform magic. For that reason, many of us have great reverence for the Moons.

Recumen, the Red Gigas, was the first Gigas we encountered. He nearly destroyed Drachma's ship, the Little Jack, with his heat rays. We were unable to destroy him, but managed to deactivate him and recover the Red Moon Crystal that controls him.

We encountered Grendel, the Green Gigas, in Ixa'taka. The king there attempted to use his power to drive away the invading Valuans, but soon lost control of him and he turned his mighty fists on everything in sight. Fortunately, we were able to subdue him until the Green Moon Crystal could be recovered.

We fought Bluheim, the Blue Gigas, in the land of Yafutoma during a battle with the Valuan Armada. Most of the ships were blown away by his Blue Winds, but Prince Enrique's flagship, the Delphinus, gave us enough power to destroy him.

Yeligar, the Yellow Gigas, had been sealed away in the ancient caverns beneath Valua. We were unable to take his Yellow Moon Crystal from him without waking him, and were forced to face his lightning in order to destroy him in the Delphinus.

Plergoth was the Purple Gigas, whom the Purple Civilization of old created by implanting the Purple Moon Crystal in an unfortunate arcwhale. Well... in the end, he passed away, and we obtained the Purple Moon Crystal... but I'd rather not dwell on it further.

The mightiest of all the Gigas was Zelos, the Silver Gigas... created by my own people. He had the power to call down the Rains of Destruction, and used them to wash the Old World away in a terrible rain of Moon Stones. In the end, we had to face his power, and... well... obviously, we were successful. But, I'd rather not talk about it just now...

The world of Arcadia, as my people called it, is a world of floating islands in an endless sky. Humans and other creatures inhabit the islands and must use airships to travel from one to the next. I'm not certain what causes the islands to float, but I believe it is the power of the Moon Stones that commonly fall and become embedded in them, as those stones are commonly used to make ships fly as well.

Silver Magic is my specialty. The Silver Moon governs life, death and void, and its magic is useful for reviving those who fall in battle as well as snuffing out a foe's life in an instant. Um, but it has some more mundane applications as well, which are especially useful for sexually active women... if any of you find that helpful in the future, I'd be happy to cast some for you.

Well, now that you've all seen, um, everything I have to offer you, I'm curious to know... have any of you done this sort of thing before? Is this your first time watching someone do... what I've done here? Or, have you... shown yourself like this to others, before this game?

If I'm honest, I think I really wanted to lose this game from the very beginning... but if I didn't try my hardest to win, it would have diminished the thrill of being... overcome. So, I promise I didn't throw the game or anything... I might have... not learned how to play on purpose, though.

Fina will remember whether she's lost to a given NPC in the past, not counting the human player or copies of Fina. The value "lost" means she's lost to them.

If the game goes 10 rounds without Fina's dialogue where she remembers the player's name ever triggering, and the female player had an objectionable name, she'll remember them as "Madam" in the next game.
If she has played against the male player for at least 10 rounds, Fina will remember they are male in the future and notice if that changes.
If she has played against the female player for at least 10 rounds, Fina will remember they are female in the future and notice if that changes.
